title: Provincial Court Family Law Act Protection Order

elements.name: ApplicantName
elements.title: What is your full name?
elements.description:
This is the name of the person 'making the Protection Order application'. If you are helping someone use this app and they are the ones who will be making the application themselves, use their name. If you are making this application on behalf of another person, use your name.

Use the name as it is written on your primary ID cards. This name will be the most useful.
elements.descFirstName: First Name is also known as Given Name
elements.descMiddleName: If you have more than one Middle Name, write them all in this box with spaces separating your Middle Names
elements.descLastName: Last Name is also known as Family Name or Surname

elements.name: ApplicantDOB
elements.title: What is your date of birth?

elements.name: Lawyer
elements.title: Has a lawyer agreed to receive court documents for you?
elements.description: You do not need a lawyer to use this service.  If you have a lawyer, you can still use this service.

elements.name: FAQLawyer1
elements.title: What if I plan to get a lawyer but I haven't done that yet?
elements.body:
You do not have a lawyer that has agreed to receive court documents for you.

After you get your lawyer, they may help you change the address for receiving court documents to their address.

elements.name: FAQLawyer2
elements.title: What if I used to have a lawyer but not anymore?
elements.body:
You do not have a lawyer that has agreed to receive court documents for you.

You will need to give an address where it is safe for you to receive court documents.

If you already have a Provincial Court Family Law file and you don't have a lawyer anymore, you may need to update your address for service.

Click here to download the form. (This link will open in a new tab.)

elements.name: ExplanationServiceAddress
elements.title:
You need to give an address where it is safe for you to receive court documents. The person protection is needed from will see this address on your court documents.

You do not have to use your home address or the address of where you are staying right now. You can pick an address where you can receive court documents such as your workplace, a family member's home or a friend's home.

elements.name: ApplicantAddress
elements.title: What is a safe address where you can receive court documents?
elements.description: The person making you (or your family) feel unsafe may need to send you court documents to this address.

elements.name: ApplicantContact
elements.title: Contact Information
elements.description: The person making you (or your family) feel unsafe will see this contact information on your court documents.

elements.name: LawyerName
elements.title: What is your lawyer's full name?

elements.name: LawyerAddress
elements.title: What is your lawyer's address?

elements.name: LawyerContact
elements.title: Lawyer's Contact Information

elements.name: ApplicantOccupation
elements.title: What is your job or profession?
elements.description: For example: Nurse, Homemaker, Carpenter, Accountant, etc.

elements.title: Please add the details of the other party in the fields below. If you need to add another party, click the 'Add Other Party' button. If you are done entering all the parties, you can move on to the next question

templateElements.title: Do you know {panel.OtherPartyName} exact date of birth?

templateElements.name: childRelationToOtherParty

elements.name: childInfoAckknowledge
elements.title: I understand that I must consider the child(ren)'s best interests with respect to each order about the child I am asking the court to make.

elements.name: childAdditionalInfo
elements.title: Would you like to share any information with the Court about the cultural, linguistic, religious and spiritual upbringing and heritage of your family, including if the child is an aboriginal child, the child's aboriginal identity?

elements.name: additionInfoDetails
elements.title: Please provide information

elements.name: additionalOtherPartyDetails
elements.title: Additional details

columns.name: partyLivingDetails
columns.title: The parties are or were spouses or live or have lived together in a marriage like relationship?

columns.name: dateOfLivingTogether
columns.title: When did the parties begin to live together in a marriage like relationship?

columns.name: isSeperated
columns.title: Are the parties now separated [define separated]?

elements.name: POSelectedWarning
elements.title: Please note: You can take in paper work for PO right away without finishing the next series of questions.

elements.name: doYouWantToApply
elements.title: Do you want to apply for a court order about any of the following?
elements.description:
Parenting arrangements how each guardian will parent their child(ren), including each guardians' parenting responsibilities for decision making about a child and the parenting time each guardian spends with a child. Parenting responsibilities may be shared or exercised separately. The only thing you can consider in making your parenting arrangements is what is in the best interest of the child.

Child support is the amount of money a parent or guardian pays to another parent or guardian to help care for the child(ren). A child has the right to be supported by both parents, whether or not the parents ever lived together or the parent has ever lived with the child.

Contact with a child time a child spends with someone who is not their guardian. This person could include a parent who is not a guardian to a child, or other people, like grandparents.

Guardianship who is responsible for a child. Only guardians have parental responsibilities and parenting time with a child. An agreement or order about parenting arrangements can say a child's guardians share parental responsibilities or parenting time, or it can say one guardian is responsible for more of the parenting decisions and has more of the parenting time with the child.

Spousal support money that one spouse pays to another spouse for their financial support after separation. A person is not entitled to spousal support in every case.

elements.name: flmChoices
elements.title: Choose all that apply
choices: Parenting Arrangements including parental responsibilities and parenting time

elements.name: noDontWantToApply
elements.title: help text about other options for resolving outside of court or other types of orders

elements.name: anyExistingOrdersAgreements
elements.title: Do you have any existing written agreement or court order about parenting arrangements including parental responsibilities and parenting time, child support, contact with a child, guardianship of a child, and/or spousal support?

elements.name: whichOrdersIncluded
elements.title: Please indicate which family law matter(s) are included in the existing written agreement(s) or court order(s).
choices: Parenting arrangements including parental responsibilities and parenting time

pages.name: Parenting Arrangements(Time)

elements.name: whatIsParentingArrangement
elements.title: Parenting arrangements include how each guardian will parent their child(ren), including each guardians' parenting responsibilities for decision making about a child and the parenting time each guardian spends with a child.  Parenting responsibilities may be shared or exercised separately. The only thing you can consider in making your parenting arrangements is what is in the best interest of the child.

elements.title: You can only apply if you are the Guardian or as part of this application you are applying to become a guardian.

elements.name: needOrderForTimeAlloc
elements.title: Do you need an order for the allocation of parenting time?
elements.description: During parenting time, a guardian has the parental responsibility of making day-to-day decisions affecting the child and having day-to-day care, control, and supervision of the child.

pages.title: Parenting Arrangements (Responsibilities)

pages.name: Existing Parenting Order

elements.name: explainExistingArrangementSection
elements.title: This series of questions will help you tell the court and the other party what you want the court to order about your existing parenting order or written agreement. Parenting time and parental responsibilities together are known as parenting arrangements. They must be in the best interests of the child. Only a guardian can have parenting time and parental responsibilities.

elements.title: Provide info...child support calculator, etc.

elements.name: whyNotAttachingCalc

elements.name: dateOfSupportPayment
elements.title: Child support payments in this amount should start on

elements.name: whyChooseDate
elements.title: Why did you choose this date?

elements.name: anyUndueHardship
elements.title: Would paying or receiving the 'guideline' amount cause you undue hardship?

elements.name: whySupportAmountCauseHardship
elements.title: The guideline amount payable would cause me undue hardship because
elements.description: Note:  If this option applies to your situation, you will need to complete the undue hardship portion of the Financial Statement, Part 4 and Part 5, in addition to any other required parts
choices: I have an unusual or excessive amount of debt I incurred to support the family prior to separation or to earn a living
I have high costs to be able to exercise parenting time with the child(ren)
I have a legal duty to support another person, such as a former spouse or a new spouse who is too ill or disabled to support themselves
I have a legal duty to support a dependent child from another relationship

elements.name: anySpecialExpenses
elements.title: Are you claiming any special or extraordinary expenses?

elements.name: question1
elements.title:
for above question: If yes, display worksheet to complete (note: Same fact sheet A from divorce app), If no, next question.

If this is the only schedule or the last of the schedule the user selected. Go to 'Financial Statement' if required. NOTE: Financial Statements are required if:
Party is the payor (If person selected their own name at Q10)
split or shared parenting time (Q4)
there is a child 19 years old or over for whom support is claimed (Q11)
a party has been acting as a parent to a child of the other party (Q2)
the paying parent earns more than $150,000 per year (Q6 or Q8)
special or extraordinary expenses are being claimed for a child (Q17)
I am claiming undue hardship (Q16)

We should know all these from previous questions. If the party is unable to complete the financial statement, and it is required, they will need to file an application asking for permission to not file it, and indicate it on this schedule.
